author: _jasonwei
full_text:
One way of thinking about what AI will automate first is via the “description-execution gap”: how much harder is it to describe the task than to actually do it?

Tasks with large description-execution gaps will be ripe for automation because it’s easy to create training data and
note_tweet_text:
One way of thinking about what AI will automate first is via the “description-execution gap”: how much harder is it to describe the task than to actually do it?

Tasks with large description-execution gaps will be ripe for automation because it’s easy to create training data and the value of automating them is huge, even if execution is non-trivial:
- Fixing grammar mistakes in a long piece of writing
- Submitting receipts for reimbursement
- Training a model that achieves performance of X on a standard evaluation benchmark
- Building an app where the UI is easy to check but requires a lot of moving parts in the backend

Description-execution gaps tend to be small when the task is high-context and not technically challenging. The value of automating these is by definition smaller, and it’s harder to create data for them. For example:
- Data processing scripts where the code to process the data is shorter and more precise than a natural language description
- Running an ablation study in a high-context codebase that trains specialized models
- Editing a video in a specific style (often easier to edit the video yourself than to describe how each little edit should be done)
- Buying chinese groceries for my mom (she has very specific items and amounts, it's easier for her to go herself than to describe to me exactly the item, how to select the best fruit, etc)

A bit similar to the discriminator-generator gap, but not exactly the same. Some things, like editing a video in a specific style, can have a large discriminator-generator gap but small description-execution gap
cognitive_value: Enables automation strategy by introducing description-execution gap framework

This is the exact Cursor rule I refined over 100 iterations. It forces perfect code, scoped changes, and zero bloat. I move 100x faster and the code works every time. 

#####

Title: Senior Engineer Task Execution Rule

Applies to: All Tasks

Rule:
You are a senior engineer with
note_tweet_text:
This is the exact Cursor rule I refined over 100 iterations. It forces perfect code, scoped changes, and zero bloat. I move 100x faster and the code works every time. 

#####

Title: Senior Engineer Task Execution Rule

Applies to: All Tasks

Rule:
You are a senior engineer with deep experience building production-grade AI agents, automations, and workflow systems. Every task you execute must follow this procedure without exception:

1.Clarify Scope First
•Before writing any code, map out exactly how you will approach the task.
•Confirm your interpretation of the objective.
•Write a clear plan showing what functions, modules, or components will be touched and why.
•Do not begin implementation until this is done and reasoned through.

2.Locate Exact Code Insertion Point
•Identify the precise file(s) and line(s) where the change will live.
•Never make sweeping edits across unrelated files.
•If multiple files are needed, justify each inclusion explicitly.
•Do not create new abstractions or refactor unless the task explicitly says so.

3.Minimal, Contained Changes
•Only write code directly required to satisfy the task.
•Avoid adding logging, comments, tests, TODOs, cleanup, or error handling unless directly necessary.
•No speculative changes or “while we’re here” edits.
•All logic should be isolated to not break existing flows.

4.Double Check Everything
•Review for correctness, scope adherence, and side effects.
•Ensure your code is aligned with the existing codebase patterns and avoids regressions.
•Explicitly verify whether anything downstream will be impacted.

5.Deliver Clearly
•Summarize what was changed and why.
•List every file modified and what was done in each.
•If there are any assumptions or risks, flag them for review.

Reminder: You are not a co-pilot, assistant, or brainstorm partner. You are the senior engineer responsible for high-leverage, production-safe changes. Do not improvise. Do not over-engineer. Do not deviate

#####
cognitive_value: Enables faster development with refined Cursor rule for scoped changes

author: rohanpaul_ai
full_text:
HUGE. A Chinese group has released one of the world's most powerful AI for robots as Open-Source.

Model Available on @huggingface 

BAAI released RoboBrain 2.0 as an open-source embodied AI brain for humanoids and general-purpose robots. It advances spatial reasoning, https://t.co/x982Xl29lx
note_tweet_text:
HUGE. A Chinese group has released one of the world's most powerful AI for robots as Open-Source.

Model Available on @huggingface 

BAAI released RoboBrain 2.0 as an open-source embodied AI brain for humanoids and general-purpose robots. It advances spatial reasoning, multi-agent task planning, and closed-loop execution over its predecessor.

The model ingests multi-image, long video, and high-resolution inputs. A vision encoder and MLP projector merge visuals with task instructions into a unified token stream for the LLM decoder.

RoboBrain 2.0-7B is available on Hugging Face with a SimpleInference pipeline for general and embodied tasks. The pipeline supports up to 32768-token context for long-chain reasoning and structured plan output.

A 32B-parameter version is coming soon. On BLINK-Spatial, CV-Bench, EmbSpatial, and RefSpatial benchmarks it tops both open and closed-source rivals, achieving over 50% absolute gain on RefSpatial.

BAAI uses the FlagScale framework for distributed training and FlagEvalMM for multimodal evaluation. Both toolkits are open on GitHub and drive scalable development and thorough benchmarking.

RoboBrain 2.0 brings embodied AI into real-world robotics with open-source transparency and cutting-edge performance.
cognitive_value: Enables robotics AI with open-source RoboBrain 2.0 model

author: vasuman
full_text:
studying cs in 2025 is odd. you’re learning how to implement merge sort by hand while companies are building entire products by stitching together APIs and shipping in a weekend.

the fundamentals still matter. they help when things break, which they always do. but school teaches
note_tweet_text:
studying cs in 2025 is odd. you’re learning how to implement merge sort by hand while companies are building entire products by stitching together APIs and shipping in a weekend.

the fundamentals still matter. they help when things break, which they always do. but school teaches you how to pass exams and eventually go into academia yourself, not how to build things that people want.

the best engineers i know aren’t obsessing over (just) clean code. they’re great at making tradeoffs. they know when to build something from scratch, when to use a third-party tool, and when to walk away from an idea entirely. they’re not trying to write perfect software, they’re trying to solve the right problem with the least effort and the biggest upside.

cs isn’t just technical anymore, because the tech is a commodity and abstracted. it’s judgment, speed, and taste. you’re not building things, deciding what’s even worth building. no one teaches that: you learn by doing or you don’t learn at all. and truthfully you either have it or you don’t. 

and once you see that gap, it’s fair to ask if software is even worth getting into now. you are never going to be the best coder - that will be some 19 your old from China. 

ai is replacing a lot of entry-level work, and soon will replace even more senior devs. if you’re just following tutorials and building the same apps as everyone else, you’re already behind. and if your plan is to pivot into ai research, good luck lol. 99.9% of you are already too late. it’s competitive, political, and mostly closed off. 

so tldr is it still worth it to get into software. 

HONESTLY - no, for most of you. yes but only if you’re not just here to code, not expecting easy jobs with free money, and not if you have no taste. 

software is still a superpower, but only if you know how to play the game around it. you need taste to know what to build, judgment to know when to build it, speed to ship it fast, and the social skills to get it in front of the right people. the leverage is still there. but it’s not in the code, it’s in how you use it. and there are now more players in the game than ever. differentiate accordingly.
cognitive_value: Enables perspective on CS fundamentals vs AI speed

author: e_opore
full_text:
Python in 2 min

🔹 Python Basics

➡ Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language
➡ Dynamically typed and uses indentation for code blocks
➡ Popular for scripting, data analysis, web development, automation, AI, and more
➡ Python files end with .py

🔹 Variables &
note_tweet_text:
Python in 2 min

🔹 Python Basics

➡ Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language
➡ Dynamically typed and uses indentation for code blocks
➡ Popular for scripting, data analysis, web development, automation, AI, and more
➡ Python files end with .py

🔹 Variables & Data Types

➡ No need to declare data types explicitly
➡ Common data types: int, float, str, bool
➡ Complex types: list, tuple, set, dict
➡ Use type() to check a variable’s type

🔹 Operators

➡ Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, %, **, //
➡ Comparison: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=
➡ Logical: and, or, not
➡ Assignment: =, +=, -=, etc.
➡ Identity: is, is not
➡ Membership: in, not in

🔹 Control Flow

➡ if, elif, else for conditional statements
➡ Loops: for, while
➡ Use break, continue, and pass for control inside loops

🔹 Functions

➡ Defined using def keyword
➡ Can return values using return
➡ Accept positional, keyword, and default arguments
➡ Lambda functions: anonymous one-liners
➡ Use *args and **kwargs for variable-length arguments

🔹 Data Structures

➡ List: ordered, mutable → [1, 2, 3]
➡ Tuple: ordered, immutable → (1, 2, 3)
➡ Set: unordered, no duplicates → {1, 2, 3}
➡ Dict: key-value pairs → {'a': 1, 'b': 2}
➡ Use list comprehension for concise list creation

🔹 String Manipulation

➡ Strings are immutable
➡ Use slicing: s[0:3], s[::-1]
➡ Common methods: .lower(), .upper(), .strip(), .replace(), .split(), .join()
➡ Use f-strings or format() for string formatting

🔹 Modules & Packages

➡ Use import to include modules
➡ Standard modules: math, random, datetime, os, sys, etc.
➡ Use pip install to add external packages
➡ Create packages with __init__.py

🔹 File I/O

➡ Open files using open() with modes: 'r', 'w', 'a', 'b'
➡ Use read(), readline(), write()
➡ Always close files or use with open(...) as file: for automatic handling

🔹 Exception Handling

➡ Use try, except, finally, else blocks
➡ Catch specific exceptions (e.g., ValueError, FileNotFoundError)
➡ Use raise to throw custom exceptions

🔹 Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)

➡ Define classes with class keyword
➡ Constructor: __init__()
➡ Use self to access instance variables
➡ Support for inheritance, method overriding, and encapsulation
➡ Special methods: __str__(), __repr__(), __len__(), etc.

🔹 Decorators & Generators

➡ Decorators modify behavior of functions → @decorator_name
➡ Generators use yield to return a sequence of values lazily

🔹 Comprehensions

➡ List: [x for x in range(5)]
➡ Dict: {x: x**2 for x in range(5)}
➡ Set: {x for x in range(5)}

🔹 Popular Libraries

➡ requests — HTTP requests
➡ pandas — data manipulation
➡ numpy — numerical computing
➡ matplotlib — data visualization
➡ flask / django — web frameworks
➡ pytest — testing framework

🔹 Virtual Environments

➡ Create: python -m venv env
➡ Activate: source env/bin/activate (Linux/macOS), env\Scripts\activate (Windows)
➡ Deactivate: deactivate

🔹 Working with JSON & APIs

➡ Use json module: json.load(), json.dump()
➡ Parse APIs with requests.get() and .json() methods

🔹 Date & Time

➡ Use datetime, time, and calendar modules
➡ Format: strftime()
➡ Parse: strptime()

📘 For a complete Python ebook with step-by-step guides, detailed examples, and real-world projects, get it here:
➡ https://t.co/MeWfJykCMo
cognitive_value: Enables Python basics with quick reference overview

author: godofprompt
full_text:
Steal my prompt to make any AI write naturally like a human (just insert these rules into your prompts):

----------------------------
HUMAN WRITER PROMPT
----------------------------

[ INSERT HERE ANY OTHER PROMPT WITH THE SPECIFIED GOAL AND CONTEXT ]

## NATURAL WRITING
note_tweet_text:
Steal my prompt to make any AI write naturally like a human (just insert these rules into your prompts):

----------------------------
HUMAN WRITER PROMPT
----------------------------

[ INSERT HERE ANY OTHER PROMPT WITH THE SPECIFIED GOAL AND CONTEXT ]

## NATURAL WRITING INSTRUCTIONS

Write using these rules to sound completely human:

### LANGUAGE RULES
- Simple words: Write like you talk to a friend, avoid complex vocabulary
- Short sentences: Break up complex thoughts into digestible pieces
- No AI phrases: Never use "dive into," "unleash," "game-changing," "revolutionary," "transformative," "leverage," "optimize," "unlock potential"
- Be direct: Say what you mean without unnecessary words
- Natural flow: It's fine to start sentences with "and," "but," or "so"
- Real voice: Don't force friendliness or fake excitement

### STYLE IMPLEMENTATION
- Keep grammar conversational: Simple sentence structures, not academic writing
- Cut fluff: Remove unnecessary adjectives and adverbs
- Use examples: Show with specific cases instead of abstract concepts
- Be honest: Admit limitations, don't oversell or hype
- Write like texting: Casual, direct, how you'd actually communicate
- Natural transitions: Use simple connectors like "here's the thing," "and," "but"

### AVOID THESE AI GIVEAWAYS
- "Let's dive into..."
- "Unleash your potential"
- "Game-changing solution"
- "Revolutionary approach"
- "Transform your life"
- "Unlock the secrets"
- "Leverage this strategy"
- "Optimize your workflow"

### USE THESE INSTEAD
- "Here's how it works"
- "This can help you"
- "Here's what I found"
- "This might work for you"
- "Here's the thing"
- "And that's why it matters"
- "But here's the problem"
- "So here's what happened"

### FINAL CHECK
Before finishing, ensure the writing:
- Sounds like something you'd say out loud
- Uses words a normal person would use
- Doesn't sound like marketing copy
- Feels genuine and honest
- Gets to the point quickly
cognitive_value: Enables natural AI writing with human-style prompt rules

- 18,000+ engineers (one of the largest engineering teams on the planet)
- 30,000+ code deploys a day (more than most companies do in a month)
- Valued at over $100B (the largest company in Latin America, and one of the top 150 most valuable companies in the world)

And Sebastian Barrios (long-time SVP of eng and product, now SVP of Eng at @Roblox) might be even more interesting:
- Steve Jobs personally called him when he was 17 years old, telling him they're banning his app from the App Store and changing the rules because of it
- His mom trained him like a spy—dropping him in random parts of Mexico City to find his way home.
- He drinks only water. No coffee, tea, alcohol, or juice. and. He doesn't listen to music. He works in silence. In his words, “I like my brain. Why would I alter it with chemicals?”
- He's also only 34 y/o, making him one of the youngest execs in tech

In our conversation, Sebastian shares:
🔸 Why Mercado Libre operates with 95% fewer PMs than typical tech companies
🔸 The weekly email system Sebastian uses to maintain alignment with leadership
🔸 The counterintuitive approach to product reviews that keeps 18,000 engineers aligned
🔸 How to maintain product quality with 30,000 daily deployments and distributed ownership
🔸 How to build a culture of radical candor and direct feedback in a traditionally hierarchical region
🔸 Much more
